segment.source: This topic introduces the key concepts of DPI and display scaling and describes what is new in Windows 8.1.
segment.target: This topic introduces the key concepts of DPI and display scaling and describes what is new in Windows 8.1.

segment.source: Dots per inch (DPI)) is the physical measurement of number of pixels in a linear inch of a display.
segment.target: Dots per inch (DPI)) is the physical measurement of number of pixels in a linear inch of a display.

segment.source: DPI is a function of display resolution and size; a higher resolution or a smaller size will lead to higher DPI, and a lower resolution or a larger size will lead to lower DPI.
segment.target: DPI is a function of display resolution and size; a higher resolution or a smaller size will lead to higher DPI, and a lower resolution or a larger size will lead to lower DPI.

segment.source: When a display has a higher DPI, pixels are smaller and closer together, so that the user interface (UI) and other displayed content appears smaller than intended.
segment.target: When a display has a higher DPI, pixels are smaller and closer together, so that the user interface (UI) and other displayed content appears smaller than intended.

segment.source: Windows® ensures that everything appears on the screen at a usable and consistent size by instructing applications (including the Windows desktop shell) to resize their content by a scale factor.
segment.target: Windows® ensures that everything appears on the screen at a usable and consistent size by instructing applications (including the Windows desktop shell) to resize their content by a scale factor.

segment.source: This number depends on the display DPI as well as other factors that impact the user’s perception of the display.
segment.target: This number depends on the display DPI as well as other factors that impact the user’s perception of the display.

segment.source: Almost all desktop displays and most current laptop displays are in the range of 95-110 DPI; for these devices, no scaling is required, and Windows sets a scale factor of 100%.
segment.target: Almost all desktop displays and most current laptop displays are in the range of 95-110 DPI; for these devices, no scaling is required, and Windows sets a scale factor of 100%.

segment.source: However, there are a number of new devices, particularly in the premium laptop and tablet markets, which have higher displays with over 200 DPI.
segment.target: However, there are a number of new devices, particularly in the premium laptop and tablet markets, which have higher displays with over 200 DPI.

segment.source: For these devices, Windows sets higher scale factors to ensure that the user experience is comfortably viewable.
segment.target: For these devices, Windows sets higher scale factors to ensure that the user experience is comfortably viewable.

segment.source: Users typically spend hours reading and working on Windows devices, so it is important to ensure that the device they are looking at is optimized for their comfort.
segment.target: Users typically spend hours reading and working on Windows devices, so it is important to ensure that the device they are looking at is optimized for their comfort.

segment.source: Therefore, it is important for Windows to present the content in the most readable way so that eye fatigue is reduced, and productivity is not impacted.
segment.target: Therefore, it is important for Windows to present the content in the most readable way so that eye fatigue is reduced, and productivity is not impacted.

segment.source: As display technology improves, this can be delivered in a combination of higher DPI displays and better scaling in Windows.
segment.target: As display technology improves, this can be delivered in a combination of higher DPI displays and better scaling in Windows.

segment.source: Windows 8 provides features that automatically adjust the default scaling to better match newer, more dense DPI displays.
segment.target: Windows 8 provides features that automatically adjust the default scaling to better match newer, more dense DPI displays.

segment.source: As Windows devices improve, high density displays will become increasingly common in enterprise environments.
segment.target: As Windows devices improve, high density displays will become increasingly common in enterprise environments.

segment.source: Enterprises are also moving towards a more mobile workforce that use laptops in meetings to project, docking solutions when at the desk.
segment.target: Enterprises are also moving towards a more mobile workforce that use laptops in meetings to project, docking solutions when at the desk.

segment.source: To ensure optimum productivity, enterprise users should not need to manage how their screens lock when they project, or how their docking solutions present their workspace when they sit down at a desk.
segment.target: To ensure optimum productivity, enterprise users should not need to manage how their screens lock when they project, or how their docking solutions present their workspace when they sit down at a desk.

segment.source: Windows 8 does this automatically for most users, but there remain some edge cases which IT professionals in enterprise environments might need to help support.
segment.target: Windows 8 does this automatically for most users, but there remain some edge cases which IT professionals in enterprise environments might need to help support.

segment.source: This topic describes how Windows automatically does the right thing in most instances, and where IT might need to step in and help the user out.
segment.target: This topic describes how Windows automatically does the right thing in most instances, and where IT might need to step in and help the user out.

segment.source: With the advent of higher DPI displays.
segment.target: With the advent of higher DPI displays.

segment.source: Windows devices that are available during and after 2013 will routinely feature DPIs that are much higher than what has been previously available.
segment.target: Windows devices that are available during and after 2013 will routinely feature DPIs that are much higher than what has been previously available.

segment.source: Instead of laptops with 13” and 1366x768 resolutions, you will see screen resolutions up to 3200x1800 at 13”.
segment.target: Instead of laptops with 13” and 1366x768 resolutions, you will see screen resolutions up to 3200x1800 at 13”.

segment.source: For these laptops to be usable, Windows scaling has to move from 100% (13.3” 1366x768) to 125% (13.3” 1600x900), 150% (10.6” 1920x1080) or 200% (13.3” 2560x1440).
segment.target: For these laptops to be usable, Windows scaling has to move from 100% (13.3” 1366x768) to 125% (13.3” 1600x900), 150% (10.6” 1920x1080) or 200% (13.3” 2560x1440).

segment.source: Before Windows 8, only 100%, 125% and 150% were automatically set to match the display; in Windows 8, 200% support has been added.
segment.target: Before Windows 8, only 100%, 125% and 150% were automatically set to match the display; in Windows 8, 200% support has been added.

segment.source: Windows 8 includes a number of feature changes that are specific for high DPI, as shown in Table 1 Windows 8.1 DPI Changes:
segment.target: Windows 8 includes a number of feature changes that are specific for high DPI, as shown in Table 1 Windows 8.1 DPI Changes:

segment.source: Viewing distance incorporated in default DPI calculation
segment.target: Viewing distance incorporated in default DPI calculation

segment.source: The first two of the above features have the biggest impact on Windows 8 usability.
segment.target: The first two of the above features have the biggest impact on Windows 8 usability.

segment.source: Improved 200% scaling support: Windows 8.1 identifies high DPI display devices on a dynamic basis and natively supports up to 200% scale factors.
segment.target: Improved 200% scaling support: Windows 8.1 identifies high DPI display devices on a dynamic basis and natively supports up to 200% scale factors.

segment.source: Windows 8 only identified a high DPI display during first boot, and only supported up to 150% scaling without user customization.
segment.target: Windows 8 only identified a high DPI display during first boot, and only supported up to 150% scaling without user customization.

segment.source: This feature ensures that users who buy premium laptops with high DPI displays will automatically receive the 200% scaling required to make content easily visible.
segment.target: This feature ensures that users who buy premium laptops with high DPI displays will automatically receive the 200% scaling required to make content easily visible.

segment.source: Per-monitor DPI: Windows 8.1 sets different scale factors for different displays, and can scale content appropriately.
segment.target: Per-monitor DPI: Windows 8.1 sets different scale factors for different displays, and can scale content appropriately.

segment.source: Windows 8 only sets a single scale factor that is applied to all displays.
segment.target: Windows 8 only sets a single scale factor that is applied to all displays.

segment.source: This feature ensures that users with High DPI devices (that is, 150% and 200% scaling laptops) who project or dock their devices with conventional 100% scaling projectors and desktop monitors display properly sized content on those screens.
segment.target: This feature ensures that users with High DPI devices (that is, 150% and 200% scaling laptops) who project or dock their devices with conventional 100% scaling projectors and desktop monitors display properly sized content on those screens.

segment.source: How these changes impact enterprise users
segment.target: How these changes impact enterprise users

segment.source: For the users on laptops with 100% scaling, the Windows 8.1 feature changes have no impact.
segment.target: For the users on laptops with 100% scaling, the Windows 8.1 feature changes have no impact.

segment.source: For users who acquire new devices that have high DPI, Windows 8.1 provides a significant benefit.
segment.target: For users who acquire new devices that have high DPI, Windows 8.1 provides a significant benefit.

segment.source: It is possible that some users will acquire devices that fall in-between, featuring Windows scaling of 125%.
segment.target: It is possible that some users will acquire devices that fall in-between, featuring Windows scaling of 125%.

segment.source: These devices can require the user or the IT professional to configure them correctly or update/tweak applications to improve usability.
segment.target: These devices can require the user or the IT professional to configure them correctly or update/tweak applications to improve usability.

segment.source: The troubleshooting section of this topic can help IT professionals identify these systems, these applications, and undertake the right mitigation tactics.
segment.target: The troubleshooting section of this topic can help IT professionals identify these systems, these applications, and undertake the right mitigation tactics.

segment.source: High DPI Support for IT Professionals
segment.target: High DPI Support for IT Professionals
